subject: Web3
title: Anti-Corruption Tools
description: A micro-lesson that makes Anti-Corruption Tools usable.

hook.text: Corruption costs the world $3.6 trillion annually. Blockchain's transparency could make it much harder to hide.

buildup.text: Aid organizations lose significant funds to corruption in developing nations. Money disappears between allocation and delivery.

discovery.text: The World Food Programme used blockchain to distribute aid in Jordan. Refugees received vouchers tracked on a ledger.

twist.text: Transparent systems only help if enforcement follows. Seeing corruption on a blockchain doesn't automatically stop it.

climax.text: Blockchain makes corruption visible. What governments do with that visibility is a human problem, not a technical one.

punchline.text: Blockchain can expose corruption. Stopping it still requires people.

quiz.question: How did the World Food Programme use blockchain?
options: To track aid distribution to refugees using a transparent ledger
